metadata.title: Synthesis and characterization of turbostratic carbons prepared by catalytic chemical vapour decomposition of acetylene

(a) Carbon obtained from 5wt.% Ni/MgO and (b) carbon obtained from 10wt.% Ni/MgO. Fig. 5 XRD patterns of carbon blacks obtained at different temperatures: (A) 500°C, (B) 700°C and (C) 1000°C. (a) Carbon obtained from 5wt.% Ni/MgO and (b) carbon obtained from 10wt.% Ni/MgO. Fig. 6 The TEM images of turbostratic carbon blacks synthesized on 10wt.% Ni/MgO catalysts at different temperatures after purifying by 5M HNO3. (A) 500°C, (B) 700°C and (C) 1000°C. Fig. 7 The SEM images of carbon blacks synthesized on 10% Ni/MgO catalysts after purifying by 5M HNO3. (A) 500°C, (B) 700°C and (C) 1000°C. Fig. 8 Thermogravimetric curves for the carbon black samples obtained on (a) 5wt.% Ni/MgO and (b) 10wt.% Ni/MgO after purification. Fig. 9 (a) The relation between T max and surface area of carbon; (b) the relation between T max and V nano. Fig. 10 Relationship between the activities and the surface areas of the catalysts (reaction temperature=550°C; pure NH3, gas flow rate=100ml/min). Fig. 11 (a) Relationship between the activity (per gram catalyst) and the Ru metal surface area of the catalyst; (b) relationship between the activity (per m2 Ru metal surface area) of the catalyst and V nano of carbon support (reaction temperature=550°C; pure NH3, gas flow rate=100ml/min). Synthesis and characterization of turbostratic carbons prepared by catalytic chemical vapour decomposition of acetylene Li Li a b Z.H. Zhu b ⁎ G.Q. Lu b ⁎⁎ Z.F. Yan a ⁎⁎ R. De Marco c a State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, CNPC Key Laboratory of Catalysis, China University of Petroleum, Dongying 257061, China b ARC Centre for Functional Nanomaterials, University of Queensland, Brisbane 4072, Australia c Department of Applied Chemistry, Curtin University of Technology, Perth 6845, Australia ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +61 7 33653528; fax: +61 7 33656074. ⁎⁎ Corresponding authors. The turbostratic mesoporous carbon blacks were prepared by catalytic chemical vapour decomposition (CCVD) of acetylene using Ni/MgO catalysts prepared by co-precipitation. The relationship between deposition conditions and the nanostructures of resultant carbon black materials was investigated. It was found that the turbostratic and textural structures of carbon blacks are dependent on the deposition temperature and nickel catalyst loading. Higher deposition temperature increases the carbon crystallite unit volume V nano and reduces the surface area of carbon samples. Moreover, a smaller V nano is produced by a higher Ni loading at the same deposition temperature. In addition of the pore structure and the active metal surface area of the catalyst, the graphitic degree or electronic conductivity of the carbon support is also a key issue to the activity of the supported catalyst. V nano is a very useful parameter to describe the effect of the crystalline structure of carbon blacks on the reactivity of carbon blacks in oxygen–carbon reaction and the catalytic activity of carbon-supported catalyst in ammonia decomposition semi-quantitatively. Keywords Carbon black Catalytic depostion Turbostratic structure Catalytic chemical vapour desorption Ammonia decomposition 1 Introduction Carbon black is a key raw material widely used as filler in elastomers [1–3], plastics [4,5], rubber [6–8], inks [9,10] and paints [11,12] to modify the mechanical, electrical and optical properties of materials. Carbon black is also receiving increasing attention for applications in battery [13–15], fuel cell electrodes [16,17], electric double-layer capacitors (EDLC) [18] and catalyst supports [19,20], due to its high surface area, corrosion resistance and electric conductivity. Carbon black is a typical turbostratic carbon material, composed of extremely small crystals of imperfect graphite. Each crystallite consists of several parallel graphitic layers but rotated around the c-axis with an interplanar spacing, d, of 0.35–0.38nm. Biscoe and Warren [21] identified those structures as intermediate between crystalline and amorphous materials, or graphite-like, quasi-crystalline structure. The size of carbon black particles, each of which consists of many graphitic crystallites, ranges from ca. 5nm to greater than 300nm. Morphology of carbon black can range from individual spherical particles to a more complex structure consisting of fused particles. Controlling combinations of these properties including crystallite structure, particle size, morphology, pore structures and surface activity creates carbon blacks fine-tuned to their end-use applications [22]. Fuel cells are promising for small-scale power supply such as automobile, portable power and distributed power generation. The hydrogen generated from carbonaceous substances (e.g. methanol and methane) is inevitably accompanied with CO x (x =1 and 2) that degrades the cell even at extremely low concentration [23–26]. As catalytic decomposition of ammonia produces zero CO x , ammonia has attracted increasing interests as a pure hydrogen carrier for fuel cells [27–30]. It has been reported that Ru is the most active catalyst in NH3 decomposition, and carbon materials are the most effective supports for the loading of Ru metal. Recent research results have shown that carbon nanotubes are better than active carbons as Ru catalyst support although the latter have a much higher surface area [31,32]. This indicates that as catalyst support, the graphitic degree or the electronic conductivity of carbon is also a critical issue, which has never been systematically addressed, while the previous studies have been mostly focussed on the pore structures. In this paper, turbostratic carbon blacks were synthesized by the catalytic chemical vapour decomposition (CCVD) of acetylene over Ni/MgO catalysts. The relationship between the structure of turbostratic carbon blacks and synthesis condition was systematically investigated. We also aim to establish a correlation between the nanostructures of acetylene carbon black and its activity in oxygen–carbon reaction and the catalytic activity of carbon-supported catalyst in ammonia decomposition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the catalysts Several Ni/MgO catalysts, containing 1, 5, 10 and 15wt.% Ni, were synthesized by the dispersed co-precipitation method. A 2M Ni(NO3)2 solution was mixed with 60ml of 2M Mg(NO3)2 and 5g of polyoxyethylene under vigorous stirring. Subsequently, a 1M Na2CO3 solution was added dropwise to the mixture. The final precipitated solution was stirred for 3h, filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at 100°C. The dried sample was calcined at 300°C for 6h in air and reduced in a 50ml/min flow rate H2 (99.99% purity) at 500°C for 6h. 2.2 Synthesis of acetylene carbon black Acetylene carbon black was prepared by the catalytic chemical vapour decomposition of acetylene over the Ni/MgO catalysts in a tubular reactor. The reduced catalysts (0.5g) were placed into the reactor and heated to a certain reaction temperatures in Ar (99.99% purity) flow. Subsequently, undiluted C2H2 (99.99% purity) was introduced into the reactor over 2h. After reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature in an Ar atmosphere. The final products were purified by washing with 5M HNO3 solution in a reflux system for 12h to remove the catalysts. The solid was then filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at room temperature. The carbons obtained on 1% Ni/MgO catalysts at 500, 700 and 1000°C are denoted as C-1-500, C-1-700 and C-1-1000, those obtained on 5 and 10% Ni/MgO catalysts denoted as C-5-500, C-5-700 and C-5-1000 and C-10-500, C-10-700 and C-10-1000, respectively. 2.3 Test of catalysts in catalytic decomposition of ammonia All the Ru catalysts were prepared by the conventional wetness incipient impregnation. A 1g carbon blacks were added in RuCl3 solution with stirring for 12h, and then were dried at 100°C for 12h. The dried samples were calcined in Ar flow at 500°C for 2h. The samples were noted as 5% Ru/carbon black. Catalytic ammonia decomposition reaction was performed in a vertical fixed-bed flow reactor at pure ammonia (purity>99.9%) under atmospheric pressure. A 0.2g (60–80mesh) catalyst was placed in the central section of reactor. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was first purged with Ar flow (purity>99.99%) to be swept, and then heated to 500°C in Ar flow with a heating rate of 10°C/min. Subsequently, the catalyst was reduced in situ in pure H2 flow at 500°C for 2h. Catalytic testing was carried out under pure NH3 (gas flow rate=350ml/min) at 550°C. Production analysis was performed on a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu) equipped with TCD, using Ar as carrier gas. 2.4 Characterization of the catalysts and turbostratic carbon blacks The morphology, microstructure and textural structure of the synthetic Ni/MgO catalysts and carbon materials were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 absorption–desorption isotherms, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and temperature programmed oxidation (TPO). The XRD patterns of the Ni/MgO catalysts and carbon samples were performed on a Rigaku MIniflex diffractometer with Co Kα radiation at a scanning rate of 2°/min in the 2θ range from 2° to 100°. The particle size was calculated from the Scherrer equation: L = K λ β cos θ where λ is the wavelength of the X-rays, θ the diffraction angle, K the shape factor, and β is the peak width at half-maximum intensity. The value of K =0.9 and 1.84 were used for L c and L a determination, respectively. L c is the layer dimension perpendicular to the basal plane, obtained from the (002) reflection and L a is the layer dimension parallel to the basal plane, calculated by the (10) reflection. In order to quantitatively characterize the volume of each quasi-graphitic crystallite unit, each graphitic crystallite is assumed to be a nano-size cylinder as shown in Fig. 1 . L a is supposed to the diameter of cylinder and L c is supposed to be the height of cylinder. The cylindrical volume of each nano-crystallite was designated as V nano: V nano = 3.14 × L a 2 × L c 4 Specific surface areas, pore size distribution and pore volume were determined by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms using a NOVA 1200 adsorption analyzer (Quantachrome, USA). Prior to measurement the samples were degassed at 200°C for 8h. Surface areas of samples (S BET) were obtained from the BET equation, which was applied in relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.25. The total pore volume is derived from the amount of vapour adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.98, by assuming that the pores are then filled with liquid N2. The pore size distribution of carbon samples were evaluated by the desorption branch of the isotherm using BJH method. The morphology and microstructure were characterization by TEM and SEM. TEM examination was conducted on a JEOL 2010 microscope with an accelerating voltage 200kV. The TEM samples were prepared by dipping ultrasonically dispersed catalysts and carbon samples in ethanol on holey carbon grids. The SEM photomicrograph of the carbon samples were taken in a JEOL 6300 microscope with Pt coating. Reactivity of carbon materials toward oxidation in oxygen was also investigated by recording weight changes using a thermogravimetric analyzer (Shimadzu TGA-50). The samples were loaded into a platinum pan and heated under N2 atmosphere from room temperature to 300°C at a heating rate of 5.0°C/min and hold at this temperature for 60min, and then heated to 800°C under air atmosphere with the 5.0°C/min heating rate. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the supported Ni catalysts The pore structures of the Ni/MgO catalysts are summarised in Table 1 . The 15wt.% Ni/MgO presents much higher surface area and pore volume than other Ni/MgO catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of Ni/MgO catalysts. For all Ni/MgO catalysts, the main peaks near 50° and 74° are attributed to MgO. The Ni particles are not detectable by XRD even at metal loading up to 5%, indicating the high dispersion of Ni catalyst on the MgO surface. With the further increase in Ni loading (10 and 15%), Ni particles emerge in the XRD patterns. Meanwhile, the peak of Mg0.4Ni0.6O distinctly exists, which indicates that Ni2+ ions diffuse partly into the MgO lattice forming a NiO–MgO solid solution after calcination and reduction at high temperature. The formation of Mg0.4Ni0.6O soild solution provides highly dispersed Ni species in the host lattice [33,34]. In addition, the wide peaks of Ni/MgO catalysts in the XRD patterns are indicative of small Ni/MgO particles prepared by dispersed co-precipitation method. The TEM image of 5wt.% Ni/MgO catalyst is shown in Fig. 3 , which shows that rod-like MgO covered with small Ni particles is formed. 3.2 Textural properties of the synthesized carbon blacks The N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the various carbon black samples by CCVD method are presented in Fig. 4 . The isotherms for the carbon black samples obtained on 10wt.% Ni/MgO catalysts at 500, 700 and 1000°C show type IV with H3-type hysteresis loop with a broad pore-size distribution, which indicates that the carbon black samples synthesized over 10wt.% Ni/MgO catalysts have mesoporous structure. The H3-type hysteresis loop indicates the slit shaped pores in the carbon black samples. The carbon sample obtained at 1000°C is essentially a nonporous solid showing the type II isotherm. Table 2 presents the quantitative results of surface area, total pore volume and pore size of the carbon blacks synthesized over different loadings of catalysts at different temperatures. The surface areas of carbon blacks obtained from the Ni/MgO vary from 12.4 to 281m2/g and pore volumes range from 0.05 to 1.06cm3/g. The surface area and pore volume of carbon black decrease with the increase in the synthesis temperature. The surface areas of carbon blacks increase with the increase in the metal loading of catalysts from 1 to 10%. However, when the metal loading increases to 15%, the surface area of carbon black obtained by CCVD method decreases significantly. 3.3 XRD studies of carbon black For XRD patterns of graphite, the (002), (100) and (101) peaks are expected at 30.9°, 49.6° and 52.3°, respectively. For the carbon blacks synthesized in this study as shown in Fig. 5 , the (100) and (101) peaks merge into a broad (10) peak around 50°, the (002) reflection shifts to a relatively lower value ca. 30°, which means that the synthesized carbon blacks have a turbostratic quasi-graphite structure [35]. The quantitative values of inter-planar distance (d 002), the layer dimension perpendicular to the basal plane (L c) and the layer dimension perpendicular to the basal plane (L a) are shown in Table 3 . The d 002 values of the carbon black samples are in the range of 0.341–0.348nm relatively lower than the reported data [36]. The d 002 values decrease slightly with the increase in pyrolysis temperature for the carbon blacks synthesized over the same loading catalysts, which means that the formed carbon black crystallites are more “compact” at higher pyrolysis temperature. L a and L c are important characteristic parameters for carbon blacks. L a represents their average diameter of the graphite crystallite and L c expresses the average stacking height of aligned graphite planes [37]. From Table 3, the values of L a and L c are 5.22–8.34 and 3.98–5.32nm, respectively, these are larger than the reported values [36], indicating the higher level of crystalline development of the carbon blacks from acetylene by CCVD method. As expected, a higher pyrolysis temperature (with the same catalyst loading) improves the graphitic degree, resulting in larger L a and L c values. The XRD patterns in Fig. 5 also show that for the carbon blacks synthesized at 1000°C, the broad (10) peak appears to split into two peaks (100) and (101), in accordance with a higher local order at a higher temperature. Therefore, the pyrolysis temperature has a crucial effect on the graphitic structure of carbon blacks. At the same pyrolysis temperature, the increase in the Ni catalyst loading results in a larger L a and a smaller L c. The volume V nano of each nano-crystallite of carbon blacks is shown in the fifth column of Table 3. For the carbon blacks synthesized over the same loading catalyst, the higher the pyrolysis temperature, the larger the V nano value. For the carbon blacks synthesized at the same temperature, the higher the Ni catalyst loading, the smaller the V nano value. It will be shown in Sections 3.5 and 3.6, V nano is a useful parameter, by which the role of the crystallite size or the graphitic degree of carbon in gas–carbon reaction or catalytic reaction with carbon as support can be described readily. 3.4 The morphology of the carbon blacks The TEM and SEM images of the carbon black particles synthesized over 10% Ni/MgO catalyst are showed in Figs. 6 and 7 . In Fig. 6, carbon blacks prepared at 500°C have curled chain-like structure formed by carbon aggregates, with the size range around 100nm. However, carbon blacks prepared at 700 and 1000°C consist of typical spherical particles, the size range around 200–250 and 250–300nm, respectively. The higher the pyrolysis temperature, the larger the synthesized carbon black particle. It is noteworthy that each carbon black particle in Fig. 6 consists of many small graphite crystallites as described in Section 3.3, and the multilayer structure of the carbon crystallite is invisible under TEM. The SEM images of the three carbon samples are shown in Fig. 7. Silk structure was observed for carbon blacks synthesized at 500°C, spherical carbon particles were observed for carbon blacks synthesized at higher pyrolysis temperature. Apparently the SEM images are corresponding to their TEM images in Fig. 6. 3.5 The oxidative reactivity of the carbon black Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) was employed to evaluate the reactivity of carbon with O2. The weight loss curves of carbon blacks in air are shown in Fig. 8 . Significant weight losses occurred in a narrow temperature range of 450–650°C. The principal characteristic TPO values, T max, at which point the maximum reactivity is observed, are enumerated in column 6 of Table 3. It is well know that the reactivity of carbon is determined by both the surface area and the surface activity of carbon. While the former can be well quantitatively measured, there are still too many uncertainties for the characterizations of the latter. There has never been a widely accepted method, which can convincingly measure the surface activity of reactivity of carbon in gas–carbon reaction. In this study, we argue that the crystallite volume of carbon is a reflection of the carbon edge sites. The smaller the crystallite volumes, the more the edge sites, and the more active the carbon surface, the lower the T max. The relationship between the T max values and surface areas of the synthesized carbon blacks is shown in Fig. 9 (a) while Fig. 9(b) shows the change of T max via V nano. As expected, the higher the surface area, the lower the T max or the more active the carbon. The results about the effect of the carbon crystalline volume on the reactivity of carbon also support our proposal: the Tmax increase with the crystalline size V nano. This is an indication that the carbon crystalline volume may provide new assistance to quantitatively characterizing the surface activity (or active surface area) of carbon in gas–carbon reaction provided a more accurate method to quantitatively determine the graphitic structure of carbon. 3.6 Catalytic activity of ammonia decomposition The active metal surface areas (S AMSA) and particle size of Ru catalysts supported on carbon were obtained by H2 chemisorption (in Table 4 ). By comparing the catalyst particle size with the S BET of the corresponding carbon supports (shown in Table 2), it can be found that the higher the surface area of the carbon support, the smaller the Ru particles on carbon supports. This indicates that a higher carbon surface area results in a better Ru dispersion. We further investigated the relationship between the active metal surface areas (by H2 chemisorption), the pore structure (by N2 adsorption) and the activities of the catalysts in ammonia decomposition. Fig. 10 shows that the correlation between the catalytic activity (by H2 chemisorption) and the BET surface area (by N2 adsorption) of the catalyst is very poor, which means that the pore structure of the catalyst may not be the key factor in ammonia decomposition. This is consistent with the literature [31]. The relationship between the activity (per gram catalyst) and the S AMSA of catalyst, shown in Fig. 11(a), is not strong either. This indicates that in addition to the BET surface area and the active metal surface area of the catalyst, there is another factor, which is very important to its catalytic activity. Fig. 11(b) shows the relationship between the activity (per unit active metal surface area) of catalyst and the V nano of the corresponding carbon support. The activity (per unit active metal surface area) of the catalyst is nearly proportional to the V nano of the carbon support. Normally for carbon materials, the larger the size of the crystallite, the more ordered the crystalline structure, the higher the graphitic degree, and the better the electronic conductivity. Any catalytic reaction is accompanied by electron transfer between the reactants and the catalysts. While much attention has been paid to the pore structures of the carbon-supported catalysts and the catalyst dispersion, the electronic conductivity of the catalyst has rarely been mentioned and has never been systematically addressed before. Fig. 11(b), which takes both the catalyst active surface area (or catalyst dispersion) and the electronic conductivity of the carbon support into account, clearly shows that the graphitic degree or the electronic conductivity of carbon support is also a critical issue to the activity of the carbon-supported catalyst. A higher graphitic degree or higher electronic conductivity of the carbon support can significantly improve the supported catalyst. We are the first group to provide such semi-quantitative results to show the importance of the graphitic degree (or the electronic conductivity) of the carbon support in the catalytic reaction. To incorporate the graphitic degree or the electronic conductivity of the carbon support in the kinetics of gas–carbon reaction and the catalytic reaction over carbon-supported catalysts is an on-going project, which will be detailed in a separate paper. 4 Conclusions Turbostratic carbon blacks were synthesized by the catalytic decomposition of acetylene at 500–1000°C on Ni/MgO catalysts. The important synthesis conditions include pyrolysis temperature, the catalyst composition and catalyst particle size. Higher pyrolysis temperature increases the carbon crystallite volume V nano or higher graphitic degree and reduces the surface area of the produced carbon. Moreover, a smaller carbon crystallite volume V nano is produced by a higher Ni loading at the same pyrolysis temperature. The morphology of carbon samples is also influenced by the pyrolysis temperature and Ni catalysts. In addition to the pore structure and the active metal surface areas, the graphitic degree or electronic conductivity of the carbon support is also a critical issue to the supported catalyst. The carbon crystallite volume V nano is a useful parameter, by which the effect of the carbon crystalline structure on the gas–carbon reaction and the catalytic activity of carbon-supported catalyst can be described effectively. coredata.dc:description: The turbostratic mesoporous carbon blacks were prepared by catalytic chemical vapour decomposition (CCVD) of acetylene using Ni/MgO catalysts prepared by co-precipitation. The relationship between deposition conditions and the nanostructures of resultant carbon black materials was investigated. It was found that the turbostratic and textural structures of carbon blacks are dependent on the deposition temperature and nickel catalyst loading. Higher deposition temperature increases the carbon crystallite unit volume V nano and reduces the surface area of carbon samples. Moreover, a smaller V nano is produced by a higher Ni loading at the same deposition temperature. In addition of the pore structure and the active metal surface area of the catalyst, the graphitic degree or electronic conductivity of the carbon support is also a key issue to the activity of the supported catalyst. V nano is a very useful parameter to describe the effect of the crystalline structure of carbon blacks on the reactivity of carbon blacks in oxygen–carbon reaction and the catalytic activity of carbon-supported catalyst in ammonia decomposition semi-quantitatively.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of turbostratic carbons prepared by catalytic chemical vapour decomposition of acetylene
